page.title: 01GENERAL DESCRIPTION.
page.content: The area is used for agriculture with few amenities. Most farmland supports the grazing of cattle and sheep, the latter inhabiting the rougher terrain. The Exmoor National Park covers part of the area. The Ralegh's Cross forest (a coniferous plantation) is part of a large private estate covering a few thousand acres of surrounding countryside. The buildings consist of farmhouses mainly, with a few abandoned dwellings - evidence of rural depopulation. The Brendon Hill Methodist Chapel, built in 1861, still stands and the Ralegh's Cross Inn proves a popular venue. The remains of a slipway, used for hauling iron ore mined locally,can still be found. Ancient monuments such as tumuli and barrows still exist throughout the area.
